data.title: A nice little visit
data.text: We visited here when we came for the NYS Field Band Championships. It's tucked inside a little street in the core of Syracuse. They asked for a $3 donation. Not allowed to take photos inside which was a bummer because they had some really interesting items. We came for the,"Freedom bound exhibit," about Syracuse's active role in the Underground Railroad. Really appreciated the "faces" carved into the basement of a church made by runaway slaves in a church basement. Did not know that the coffin company used for Jack & Jacquline Kennedy is in Syracuse. Smith & Corona typewriters made in Syracuse. Who knew? I bought rings made out of discarded typewriter keys. Cool stuff. Nice little visit, worth the stop.

data.title: Research Center was very helpful!
data.text: We were researching family genealogy. Sarah was extremely helpful, and quickly gave us resources to use, listened to our issues, and made good suggestions that helped us find information we were looking for on our family. The research center is very well organized and has a wealth of information. Well worth our time and visit.

data.title: Part of the local heritage
data.text: This is a smallish but interesting museum setting. The staff are dedicated to Onondaga history, and the displays are interesting and accurate. I visit every few years to see the changes, and always come out glad that I went.

data.title: Local matters
data.text: The Executive Director, Gregg knows how to integrate and publicize the importance of this agency in Central New York.  I am always impressed and excited to visit this museum in Syracuse New York.  We are very fortunate to have his leadership and wisdom at this agency!

data.title: Interesting and inexpensive!
data.text: A very neat place to spend the afternoon. It's very quiet in the museum - not a lot of visitors, but it's not for lack of quality displays and great local historic artifacts. The gift shop is pretty fun as well.

data.title: Great history of Syracuse and Onondaga County
data.text: One of my favorite places to visit. Very interesting displays of the local history. Well worth a visit.

data.title: Great Local History
data.text: A very nice local museum highlighting local history.  Good for a two hour visit.  There is a lot to see if you're interested in local history.

data.title: Local Syracuse History
data.text: If you would like a place to see the history archives of Syracuse history, the Onondaga Historical Association is the place to visit.  They have displays of Syracuse History and also have specials displays on occasions during Christmas, Centennial, Special collaborations, etc.  It is also a great place to do research for college papers, grant writing for statistics,  genealogy, etc.  Great to take students for a visit  and get a sense of local history.  If planning, call ahead to get a docent to lead a tour.

data.title: Terrific Place to Visit!
data.text: So much to see and learn about the local area. Great exhibits! Very well done. Excellent gift shop. Don't miss the Onondaga Historical Association.

data.title: Local Museum is worth the visit!
data.text: Saw a great exhibit of fashions over the decades, put on my Syracuse University.  Excellently done and very informative.  The good news is you won't need to stand in line!

data.title: Wow! Great History!
data.text: This a like many county historical societies, a real gem! Local Syracuse history you want, local Syracuse history you get! Good in-depth look at local issues and history through the years. Great audiovisual aids also. Take the time to really enjoy all there is to offer. Donations? How can you go wrong on the price. Put some money in for their support! They are worth it!!

data.title: Central New Yorkers - Embrace your heritage!
data.text:
I have lived in CNY for almost 30 years and finally decided to take the kids to this little museum in Syracuse.   Entry is free, but a $3/person contribution is suggested.   The OHA highlights the many innovations of CNY manufacturers (Syracuse China, Franklin Cars, Carrier Air Conditioners, Marsellus Casket...) which regrettably reminds us that none of these fine companies operates in the area any longer.   Another highlight is the exhibit on abolition, showing that while CNY eventually came to embrace abolition by the mid 19th century, we took our time getting there.    

My teenagers and I spent about an hour going through the museum.  A nice way to pass the time.

data.title: Lots of local history to see and learn at the Onondaga Historical Association
data.text: A nice local historic museum that will make you feel good about Syracuse.  A lot of industry and events were invented in Syracuse, like the Shoe size device that you find in every show store in the world, and the 24-second shot clock used in college and professional basketball around the world.  It's worth the time to visit, and the entry fee is a donation.

data.title: Visit this local museum that goes well beyond most!
data.text: Combine this visit with Erie Canal and Salt museums for a thorough and enjoyable educational visit in Syracuse.  Very well-organized and 'stocked' historical museum, including area Native American artifacts.

data.title: Expensive
data.text: I came there to use the research library.  I don't mind paying for admission since I wasn't a member.  However, the price for photocopies were ridiculous and they wanted to charge for taking pictures as well.  The staff was very helpful, but I wouldn't go back there unless I absolutely had to.

data.title: It never gets old.
data.text: Our trip was nice. It was a quiet trip through history. We were awed by how much was able to be seen. And there are priceless items in the giftshop that made great gifts.

data.title: Lovely place to learn local history
data.text: This is a small but lovely museum featuring authentic exhibits from Onondaga Counties history, great place to go if you are a fan of local history. The gift shop also sells authentic maps from bygone eras if you wish to take an authentic piece of local history from the 1800s or early 1900s.

data.title: Great visit!
data.text: Everything you ever wanted to know about Syracuse and more can be found in this 2-story building on Montgomery St. There is a whole section dedicated to SU Sports, more on SyracuseUniversity, downtown, the Erie Canal, trains running through Syracuse and life in general in the early 1900's and before. Very interesting--we went as a church group and spent the better part of an afternoon there and could have stayed longer. Very nice. No admission fee, but donations accepted.

data.title: Small but Mighty
data.text: I try to go to the OHA as often as I can. Their knowledge, the artifacts and photographs used in the displays are always enlightening and informative. They also offer great outreach programs for the community. Their Halloween tour of Oakwood Cemetery is great fun;  they send reenactors into school classrooms and meetings.  They recently worked with Appleseed Productions on displays and obtaining authentic props and costumes for their production of The Civil War: the Musical. OHA is a great asset to our community.

data.title: Great Intro to Syracuse
data.text: The history of Syracuse is really on display.  The displays are not made for quick glances and a walkby.  There is a very good amount of depth.  New exhibits are done frequently and the shop has very good array of significant publications, maps, art, etc.  This is not a shallow "hands on" simpleton type amusement park museum.  This muaeum is for those with a serious interest in the city, its people, art, history, etc.  I have visited it several times over the years and I think it is better than ever.
